factoid: Prince Vasíli repeated the question "I am asking you when you last heard from Bolkónski" a third time to Pierre.
Prince Vasíli said "How absent-minded you are, my dear fellow" to Pierre.
Prince Vasíli smiled.
Pierre noticed that everyone was smiling at Prince Vasíli and at Hélène.
Pierre thought "Well, what of it, if you all know it?".
Pierre thought "What of it? It’s the truth!".
Pierre smiled a gentle childlike smile.
Hélène smiled.
Prince Vasíli repeated the question "When did you get the letter?" to Pierre.
Prince Vasíli repeated the question "Was it from Olmütz?" to Pierre.
Prince Vasíli pretended to want to know this to settle a dispute.
Pierre thought "How can one talk or think of such trifles?".
Pierre answered "Yes, from Olmütz," with a sigh.
After supper, Pierre followed the others into the drawing room.
Some guests dispersed without taking leave of Hélène.
Some guests approached Hélène for a moment and then hurried away, refusing to let her see them off.
The diplomatist left the drawing room while preserving a mournful silence.
The diplomatist pictured the vanity of his diplomatic career compared to Pierre's happiness.
The old general grumbled at his wife when she asked about his leg.
The old general thought "Oh, the old fool."
The old general thought "That Princess Hélène will be beautiful still when she’s fifty."
Anna Pávlovna whispered "I think I may congratulate you" to Princess Hélène while kissing her soundly.
Anna Pávlovna said "If I hadn’t this headache I’d have stayed longer."
Princess Hélène did not reply because she was tormented by jealousy of her daughter's happiness.
While guests were taking leave, Pierre remained alone with Hélène in the little drawing room.
Pierre had often remained alone with Hélène during the last six weeks, but had never spoken to her about love.
Pierre felt that it was inevitable to express love, but could not decide to take the final step.
Pierre felt ashamed and felt he was occupying someone else's place beside Hélène.
An inner voice whispered to Pierre "This happiness is not for you."
The inner voice also said "This happiness is for those who have not in them what there is in you."
Pierre asked Hélène whether she was satisfied with the party.
Hélène replied that this name day had been one of the pleasantest she had ever had.
Some nearest relatives had not yet left and were sitting in the large drawing room.
Prince Vasíli approached Pierre with languid footsteps.
Pierre rose and said it was getting late.
Prince Vasíli gave Pierre a look of stern inquiry, as if Pierre's words were strange.
Prince Vasíli changed expression, drew Pierre's hand downwards, made him sit down, and smiled affectionately.
Prince Vasíli asked his daughter Lëlya, turning to her with a careless tone of habitual tenderness.
Prince Vasíli turned again to Pierre.
Prince Vasíli said "Sergéy Kuzmích—From all sides—" while unbuttoning the top button of his waistcoat.
Pierre smiled, showing he knew that Prince Vasíli was not interested in the story about Sergéy Kuzmích.
Prince Vasíli saw that Pierre knew this.
Prince Vasíli muttered something and left.
Pierre perceived that Prince Vasíli was disconcerted.
Pierre saw Prince Vasíli's discomposure, looked at Hélène who seemed disconcerted, and her look seemed to say "Well, it is your own fault."
Pierre thought "The step must be taken but I cannot, I cannot!".
Pierre spoke about indifferent matters, about Sergéy Kuzmích, asking what the point of the story was because he had not heard it properly.
Hélène answered with a smile, saying she too had missed it.
Prince Vasíli returned to the drawing room.
Princess Hélène was talking in low tones to an elderly lady about Pierre.
Princess Hélène said "Of course, it is a very brilliant match, but happiness, my dear...".
The elderly lady replied "Marriages are made in heaven."
